Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a HPC System: Computing for Sustainability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, acquiring a new high performance computing (HPC) platform, aims to accelerate knowledge discovery, to provide external visibility, and to help problems of national need and societal benefit while supporting research from approximately 30 investigators from 20 departments in 6 colleges. The work builds on the expertise of scientists and the institutional focus on simulation- and data-driven science to create computing infrastructure that enables advances in the following four areas:

- Sustainable Energy: The new HPC cluster enables high throughput analysis and helps identify future technologies (such as wind, solar, and bioenergy) while serving as the key platform for computational materials research in catalysis, batteries, 2D materials and organic electronics for virtual exploration design and control.

- Digital Agriculture: The institution emphasizes microbial organisms for bio-renewable production, plant science research emphasizing biotechnology of important cereal crops (e.g., maize, barley, and soybeans) genomic advances, phenotypic prediction, precision agriculture, climate sciences, and sustainability of farming practices. Thus the research efforts span microbial, plant, and animal species, all of which are becoming more and more data driven.

- Sustainable Healthcare: The HPC platform supports (with data-driven approaches for translational health) basic applications to health care in nanoparticle synthesis and targeted drug delivery mechanisms, identification of biomarkers for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, and modeling of multi-phase flow physics for sustainable pharmaceutical applications. The institution's biomedical program spans veterinary medicine, sciences, human sciences, and engineering schools.

- HPC Research and Training: The infrastructure enables continuation of training activities to prepare a globally-engaged HPC-aware workforce. Hardware, software, and training methods are under development to design robust, comprehensive, open, science-driven, user-friendly cyberinfrastructure consisting of standardized and curated datasets of interest with processing capabilities.

Broader Impacts:
This proposal addresses three main classes of broader impacts:
- Availability of computational algorithms to the broader research community as open-source codes, enables broad impact (national and societal) on sustainability efforts in energy, food, healthcare, and infrastructure design;

- Enhancing and enabling new collaborative efforts by enriching the current research infrastructure that incorporates HPC into advanced course to train undergraduates and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in computational modeling and algorithm development; and

- Availability of time to primarily undergraduate institutions coupled with active recruitment plans to attract women, underrepresented minorities, and first generation students to the institution.
These goals will be achieved in conjunction with two NSF awards: RED RIDE and S_STEM ECSEL.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project enabled/created enabled many HPC users at Iowa State University to perform innovative research. The research has just begun and will continue to be performed over the next few years. The research outcomes are in the following four thrust areas.

 

Thrust 1: Sustainable Energy including exploring wind energy, biofuels, and solar energy and developing green buildings.

 

Thrust 2: Digital agriculture including climate modelling, high throughput sequencing, and data driven agriculture innovation and associated studies.

 

Thrust 3: Sustainable Healthcare including chemical operations, biomarker identification, and cardiovascular fluid structure interactions.

 

Thrust 4: HPC Research, Training and Workforce Development including HPC algorithms development and studying hardware and infrastructure.

 

A few outcomes of the science enabled by CyEnce are described below.

 

Surrogate models to explore structure-property relationships: The microstructure determines the photovoltaic performance of a thin film organic semiconductor film. The relationship between microstructure and performance is usually highly non-linear and expensive to evaluate, thus making microstructure optimization challenging. We have developed a data-driven approach for mapping the microstructure to photovoltaic performance using deep convolutional neural networks. We characterize this approach in terms of two critical metrics, its generalizability (has it learnt a reasonable map?), and its interpretability (can it produce meaningful microstructure characteristics that influence its prediction?). A surrogate model that exhibits generalizability and interpretability features is particularly useful for subsequent design exploration.

 

Champion morphologies using design optimization: The microstructure ? spatial distribution of electron donor and acceptor domains ? plays an important role in determining the photocurrent in thin film organic solar cells (OSCs). Optimizing the microstructure can lead to higher photo current generation, and is an active area of experimental research. We frame the microstructure design optimization problem in terms of designing the interface between the donor and acceptor regions, and thus pose it as a surface representation and optimization problem. Our results show substantial improvement in current density compared to the bulk-heterojunction microstructures. These results provide promising microstructures for experimental groups to fabricate.

 

Computational Fluid Dynamics Modeling: An Euler-Euler model incorporating pseudo-turbulent heat transfer: An Eulerian-Eulerian model incorporating pseudo-turbulence effects (two-fluid model) is widely used for computational fluid dynamics simulations of gas?solid flows. For non-isothermal flows, the averaged conservation equations solved in the two-fluid model require closures for drag, gas?solid heat transfer, pseudo-turbulent velocity fluctuations and the pseudo-turbulent heat flux (PTHF), and is therefore expensive. Based on our analysis, of the thermal energy budget, we showed that the neglecting PTHF can have a significant contribution and neglecting it can lead to large errors. Thus our research leads to more accurate designs.

 

Precision agriculture. Researchers across agriculture including engineers, agronomists, evolutionary biologists, and animal scientists advanced their research using NOVA. The projects include modelling conservation strategies on watershed performance, creating genome assembly and annotation products, conducting genome-wide association and genomic prediction analyses for agronomic trait improvement, and developing machine learning algorithms to detect novel antimicrobial resistance genes across many species. This research will have significant impact on both food production and studying antimicrobial resistance.  Our research will potentially unlock the use of these strategies for broad adoption of biotech solutions to food, feed, and fuel needs, which are anticipated to escalate in the coming decades. 

 

Making Deep Neural Networks (DNN)-based Machine Learning Inferences Robust and Efficient. Specialized hardware accelerators, such as Tensor Processing Unit (TPU), are used to support inference engines for trained models. These complex machines have two issues. They are not very fault tolerant and may yield poor results when individual components fail. Also, they long time to compute due to a large number of computation steps involved. We developed methods to make such computation fault-resistance by developing fault mitigation methods. We also developed methods to reduce time complexity of inference computations through network pruning methods and quantization of data precision without significantly impacting the accuracy of computation
